lines.value:
Electra
By Euripides
Written 420-410 B.C.E
Translated by E. P. Coleridge

O Argos, ancient land, and streams of Inachus, whence on a 
day king Agamemnon sailed to the realm of Troy, carrying his warriors aboard 
a thousand ships; and after he had slain Priam who was reigning in Ilium 
and captured the famous city of Dardanus, he came hither to Argos and has 
set up high on the temple-walls many a trophy, spoil of the barbarians. 
Though all went well with him in Troy, yet was he slain in his own palace 
by the guile of his wife Clytemnestra and the hand of Aegisthus, son of 
Thyestes. So he died and left behind him the ancient sceptre of Tantalus, 
and Aegisthus reigns in his stead, with the daughter of Tyndareus, Agamemnon's 
queen, to wife. Now as for those whom he left in his halls, when he sailed 
to Troy, his son Orestes and his tender daughter Electra,-the boy Orestes, 
as he was like to be slain by Aegisthus, his sire's old foster-father secretly 
removed to the land of Phocis and gave to Strophius to bring up, but the 
maid Electra abode in her father's house, and soon as she had budded into 
maidenhood, came all the princes of Hellas asking her hand in marriage. 
But Aegisthus kept her at home for fear she might bear a son to some chieftain 
who would avenge Agamemnon, nor would he betroth her unto any. But when 
e'en thus there seemed some room for fear that she might bear some noble 
lord a child by stealth and Aegisthus was minded to slay her, her mother, 
though she had a cruel heart, yet rescued the maiden from his hand. For 
she could find excuses for having slain her husband, but she feared the 
hatred she would incur for her children's murder. Wherefore Aegisthus devised 
this scheme; on Agamemnon's son who had escaped his realm by flight he 
set a price to be paid to any who should slay him, while he gave Electra 
to me in marriage, whose ancestors were citizens of Mycenae. It is not 
that I blame myself for; my family was noble enough, though certainly impoverished, 
and so my good birth suffers. By making for her this weak alliance he thought 
he would have little to fear. For if some man of high position had married 
her, he might have revived the vengeance for Agamemnon's murder, which 
now is sleeping; in which case Aegisthus would have paid the penalty. But 
Cypris is my witness that I have ever respected her maidenhood; she is 
still as though unwed. Unworthy as I am, honour forbids that I should so 
affront the daughter of a better man. Yea, and I am sorry for Orestes, 
hapless youth, who is called my kinsman, to think that he should ever return 
to Argos and behold his sister's wretched marriage. And whoso counts me 
but a fool for leaving a tender maid untouched when I have her in my house, 
to him I say, he measures purity by the vicious standard of his own soul, 
a standard like himself.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
ELECTRA enters from the hut, carrying a water pitcher on her head. She 
is meanly clad.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
O sable night, nurse of the golden stars! beneath thy pall 
I go to fetch water from the brook with my pitcher poised upon my head, 
not indeed because I am forced to this necessity, but that to the gods 
I may display the affronts Aegisthus puts upon me, and to the wide firmament 
pour out my lamentation for my sire. For my own mother, the baleful daughter 
of Tyndareus, hath cast me forth from her house to gratify her lord; for 
since she hath borne other children to Aegisthus she puts me and Orestes 
on one side at home.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Oh! why, poor maiden, dost thou toil so hard on my behalf, 
thou that aforetime wert reared so daintily? why canst thou not forego 
thy labour, as I bid thee?
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
As a god's I count thy kindness to me, for in my distress thou 
hast never made a mock at me. 'Tis rare fortune when mortals find such 
healing balm for their cruel wounds as 'tis my lot to find in thee. Wherefore 
I ought, though thou forbid me, to lighten thy labours, as far as my strength 
allows, and share all burdens with thee to ease thy load. Thou hast enough 
to do abroad; 'tis only right that I should keep thy house in order. For 
when the toiler cometh to his home from the field, it is pleasant to find 
all comfortable in the house.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
If such thy pleasure, go thy way; for, after all, the spring 
is no great distance from my house. And at break of day I will drive my 
steers to my glebe and sow my crop. For no idler, though he has the gods' 
names ever on his lips, can gather a livelihood without hard work.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
ELECTRA and the PEASANT go out. A moment later ORESTES and PYLADES 
enter.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
Ah Pylades, I put thee first 'mongst men for thy love, thy 
loyalty and friendliness to me; for thou alone of all my friends wouldst 
still honour poor Orestes, in spite of the grievous plight whereto I am 
reduced by Aegisthus, who with my accursed mother's aid slew my sire. I 
am come from Apollo's mystic shrine to the soil of Argos, without the knowledge 
of any, to avenge my father's death upon his murderers. Last night went 
unto his tomb and wept thereon, cutting off my hair as an offering and 
pouring o'er the grave the blood of a sheep for sacrifice, unmarked by 
those who lord it o'er this land. And now though I enter not the walled 
town, yet by coming to the borders of the land I combine two objects; I 
can escape to another country if any spy me out and recognize me, and at 
the same time seek my sister, for I am told she is a maid no longer but 
is married and living here, that I may meet her, and, after enlisting her 
aid in the deed of blood, learn for certain what is happening in the town. 
Let us now, since dawn is uplifting her radiant eye, step aside from this 
path. For maybe some labouring man or serving maid will come in sight, 
of whom we may inquire whether it is here that my sister hath her home. 
Lo! yonder I see a servant bearing a full pitcher of water on her shaven 
head; let us sit down and make inquiry of this bond-maid, if haply we may 
glean some tidings of the matter which brought us hither, Pylades.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
They retire a little, as ELECTRA returns from the 
spring.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
The CHORUS OF ARGIVE COUNTRY-WOMEN enter. The following lines between 
ELECTRA and the CHORUS are sung responsively.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
strophe
O Electra, daughter of Agamemnon, to thy rustic cot I come, for a messenger 
hath arrived, a highlander from Mycenae, one who lives on milk, announcing 
that the Argives are proclaiming a sacrifice for the third day from now, 
and all our maidens are to go to Hera's temple.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Kind friends, my heart is not set on festivity, nor do necklaces 
of gold cause any flutter in my sorrowing bosom, nor will I stand up with 
the maidens of Argos to beat my foot in the mazy dance. Tears have been 
my meat day and night; ah misery! See my unkempt hair, my tattered dress; 
are they fit for a princess, a daughter of Agamemnon, or for Troy which 
once thought of my father as its captor?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
antistrophe
Mighty is the goddess; so come, and borrow of me broidered robes for apparel 
and jewels of gold that add a further grace to beauty's charms. Dost think 
to triumph o'er thy foes by tears, if thou honour not the gods? 'Tis not 
by lamentation but by pious prayers to heaved that thou, my daughter, wilt 
make fortune smile on thee.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
No god hearkens to the voice of lost Electra, or heeds the 
sacrifices offered by my father long ago. Ah woe for the dead! woe for 
the living wanderer, who dwelleth in some foreign land, an outcast and 
vagabond at a menial board, sprung though he is of a famous sire! Myself, 
too, in a poor man's hut do dwell, wasting my soul with grief, an exile 
from my father's halls, here by the scarred hill-side; while my mother 
is wedded to a new husband in a marriage stained by blood.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Many a woe to Hellas and thy house did Helen, thy mother's 
sister, cause.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value: catching sight of ORESTES AND PYLADES
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Stay, poor maid; fear no violence from me.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: O Phoebus Apollo I beseech thee spare my life.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Give me the lives of others more my foes than thou!
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Begone! touch me not! thou hast no right to.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: There is none I have a better right to touch.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: How is it then thou waylayest me, sword in hand, near my house?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Wait and hear, and thou wilt soon agree with me
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Here I stand; I am in thy power in any case, since thou art 
the stronger.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: I am come to thee with news of thy brother.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: O best of friends! is he alive or dead?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Alive; I would fain give thee my good news first.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: God bless thee! in return for thy welcome tidings.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: I am prepared to share that blessing between us.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: In what land is my poor brother spending his dreary exile?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
His ruined life does not conform to the customs of any one 
city.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Surely he does not want for daily bread?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Bread he has, but an exile is a helpless man at best.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: What is this message thou hast brought from him?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: He asks, "Art thou alive? and if so, How art thou faring?"
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Well, first thou seest how haggard I am grown.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: So wasted with sorrow that I weep for thee.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Next mark my head, shorn and shaven like a Scythian's.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Thy brother's fate and father's death no doubt disturb thee.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Yes, alas! for what have I more dear than these?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Ah! and what dost thou suppose is dearer to thy brother?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: He is far away, not here to show his love to me.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Wherefore art thou living here far from the city?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I am wedded, sir; a fatal match!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Alas! for thy brother; I pity him. Is thy husband of Mycenae?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
He is not the man to whom my father ever thought of betrothing 
me.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Tell me all, that I may report it to thy brother.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I live apart from my husband in this house.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: The only fit inmate would be a hind or herd.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Poor he is, yet he displays a generous consideration for me.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Why, what is this consideration that attaches to thy husband?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: He has never presumed to claim from me a husband's rights.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Is he under a vow of chastity? or does he disdain thee?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: He thought he had no right to flout my ancestry.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: How was it he was not overjoyed at winning such a bride?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: He does not recognize the right of him who disposed of my hand.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: I understand; he was afraid of the vengeance of Orestes hereafter.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: There was that fear, but he was a virtuous man as well.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Ah! a noble nature this! He deserves kind treatment.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Yes, if ever the wanderer return.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: But did thy own mother give in to this?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
'Tis her husband, not her children that a woman loves, sir 
stranger.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Wherefore did Aegisthus put this affront on thee?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
His design in giving me to such a husband was to weaken my 
offspring
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
To prevent thee bearing sons, I suppose, who should punish 
him?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: That was his plan; God grant I may avenge me on him for it!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Does thy mother's husband know that thou art yet a maid?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: He does not; our silence robs him of that knowledge.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Are these women friends of thine, who overhear our talk?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: They are, and they will keep our conversation perfectly secret.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: What could Orestes do in this matter, if he did return?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Canst thou ask? Shame on thee for that! Is not this the time 
for action?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: But suppose he comes, how could he slay his father's murderers?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
By boldly meting out the same fate that his father had meted 
out to him by his foes.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Wouldst thou be brave enough to help him slay his mother?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Aye, with the self-same axe that drank my father's blood.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Am I to tell him this, and that thy purpose firmly holds?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Once I have shed my mother's blood o'er his, then welcome death!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Ah! would Orestes were standing near to hear that!
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I should not know him, sir, if I saw him.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: No wonder; you were both children when you parted.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: There is only one of my friends would recognize him.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
The man maybe who is said to have snatched him away from being 
murdered?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Yes, the old servant who tended my father's childhood long 
ago.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Did thy father's corpse obtain burial?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Such burial as it was, after his body had been flung forth 
from the palace.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
O God! how awful is thy story! Yes, there is a feeling, arising 
even from another's distress, that wrings the human heart. Say on, that 
when know the loveless tale, which yet I needs must hear, I may carry it 
to thy brother. For pity, though it has no place in ignorant natures, is 
inborn in the wise; still it may cause trouble to find excessive cleverness 
amongst the wise.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
I too am stirred by the same desire as the stranger. For dwelling 
so far from the city I know nothing of its ills, and I should like to hear 
about them now myself.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
I will tell you, if I may; and surely I may tell a friend about 
my own and my father's grievous misfortunes. Now since thou movest me to 
speak, I entreat thee, sir, tell Orestes of our sorrows; first, describe 
the dress I wear, the load of squalor that oppresses me, the hovel I inhabit 
after my royal home; tell him how hard I have to work at weaving clothes 
myself or else go barely clad and do without; how I carry home on my head 
water from the brook; no part have I in holy festival, no place amid the 
dance; a maiden still I turn from married dames and from Castor too, to 
whom they betrothed me before he joined the heavenly host, for I was his 
kinswoman. Meantime my mother, 'mid the spoils of Troy, is seated on her 
throne, and at her foot-stool slaves from Asia stand and wait, captives 
of my father's spear, whose Trojan robes are fastened with brooches of 
gold. And there on the wall my father's blood still leaves a deep dark 
stain, while his murderer mounts the dead man's car and fareth forth, proudly 
grasping in his blood-stained hands the sceptre with which Agamemnon would 
marshal the sons of Hellas. Dishonoured lies his grave; naught as yet hath 
it received of drink outpoured or myrtle-spray, but bare of ornament his 
tomb is left. Yea, and 'tis said that noble hero who is wedded to my mother, 
in his drunken fits, doth leap upon the grave, and pelt with stones my 
father's monument, boldly gibing at us on this wise, "Where is thy son 
Orestes? Is he ever coming in his glory to defend thy tomb?" Thus is Orestes 
flouted behind his back. Oh! tell him this, kind sir, I pray thee. And 
there be many calling him to come,-I am but their mouthpiece,-these suppliant 
hands, this tongue, my broken heart, my shaven head, and his own father 
too. For 'tis shameful that the sire should have destroyed Troy's race 
and the son yet prove too weak to pit himself against one foe unto the 
death, albeit he has youth and better blood as well.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Lo! here is thy husband hurrying homeward, his labour done.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
entering and catching sight of strangers talking to 
ELECTRA
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
Dear husband, be not suspicious of me. For thou shalt hear 
the truth; these strangers have come to bring me news of Orestes. Good 
sirs, pardon him those words.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: What say they? is that hero yet alive and in the light of day?
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value: He is; at least they say so, and I believe them.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Surely then he hath some memory of his father and thy wrongs?
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value: These are things to hope for; a man in exile is helpless.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: What message have they brought from Orestes?
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value: He sent them to spy out my evil case.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Well, they only see a part of it, though maybe thou art telling 
them the rest.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value: They know all; there is nothing further they need ask.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Long ere this then shouldst thou have thrown open our doors 
to them. Enter, sirs; for in return for your good tidings, shall ye find 
such cheer as my house affords. Ho! servants, take their baggage within; 
make no excuses, for ye are friends sent by one I love; and poor though 
I am, yet will I never show meanness in my habits.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
'Fore heaven! is this the man who is helping thee to frustrate 
thy marriage, because he will not shame Orestes?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: This is he whom they call my husband, woe is me!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Ah! there is no sure mark to recognize a man's worth; for human 
nature hath in it an element of confusion. For I have seen ere now the 
son of noble sire prove himself a worthless knave, and virtuous children 
sprung from evil parents; likewise dearth in a rich man's spirit, and in 
a poor man's frame a mighty soul. By what standard then shall we rightly 
judge these things? By wealth? An evil test to use. By poverty then? Nay, 
poverty suffers from this, that it teaches a man to play the villain from 
necessity. To martial prowess must I turn? But who could pronounce who 
is the valiant man merely from the look of his spear? Better is it to leave 
these matters to themselves without troubling. For here is a man of no 
account in Argos, with no family reputation to boast, one of the common 
herd, proved a very hero. A truce to your folly! ye self-deceivers, swollen 
with idle fancies; learn to judge men by their converse, and by their habits 
decide who are noble. Such are they who rule aright both states and families; 
while those forms of flesh, devoid of intellect, are but figure-heads in 
the market-place. The strong arm, again, no more than the weak awaits the 
battle-shock, for this depends on natural courage. Well! absent or present, 
Agamemnon's son, whose business brings us here, deserves this of us, so 
let us accept a lodging in this house.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
ORESTES, PYLADES and their attendants go into the 
hut.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Electra, I feel a warmer glow of joy suffuse my heart than 
ever heretofore; perchance our fortune, moving on at last, will find a 
happy resting-place.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
O reckless man, why didst thou welcome strangers like these, 
so far beyond thy station, knowing the poverty of thy house?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Why? if they are really as noble as they seem, surely they 
will be equally content with rich or humble fare.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
Well. since thou hast made this error, poor man as thou art, 
go to my father's kind old foster-sire; on the bank of the river Tanaus, 
the boundary 'twixt Argos and the land of Sparta, he tends his flocks, 
an outcast from the city; bid him come hither to our house and some provision 
for the strangers' entertainment. Glad will he be, and will offer thanks 
to heaven to hear that the child, whom once he saved, is yet alive. I shall 
get nothing from my mother from my ancestral halls; for we should rue our 
message, were she to learn, unnatural wretch! that Orestes liveth.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
I will take this message to the old man, if it seem good to 
thee; but get thee in at once and there make ready. A woman, when she chooses, 
can find dainties in plenty to garnish a feast. Besides, there is quite 
enough in the house to satisfy them with food for one day at least. 'Tis 
in such cases, when I come to muse thereon, that I discern the mighty power 
of wealth, whether to give to strangers, or to expend in curing the body 
when it falls sick; but our daily food is a small matter; for all of us, 
rich as well as poor, are in like case, as soon as we are satisfied.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value: The PEASANT departs as ELECTRA enters the hut.
lines.speaker: PEASANT

lines.value:
The OLD MAN, the former servant of Agamemnon, enters. ELECTRA presently 
appears at the door of the hut.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Where is the young princess, my mistress, Agamemnon's daughter, 
whom I nursed in days gone by? Oh! how steep is the approach to this house, 
a hard climb for these old wasted feet of mine! Still, to reach such friends 
as these, I must drag my bent old back and tottering knees up it. Ah, daughter!-for 
I see thee now at thy door,-lo! I have brought the this tender lamb from 
my own flock, having taken it from its dam, with garlands too and cheese 
straight from the press, and this flask of choice old wine with fragrant 
bouquet; 'tis small perhaps, but pour a cup thereof into some weaker drink, 
and it is a luscious draught. Let some one carry these gifts into the house 
for the guests; for I would fain wipe from my eyes the rising tears on 
this tattered cloak.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
Why stands the tear-drop in thine eye, old friend? Is it that 
my sorrows have been recalled to thee after an interval? or art thou bewailing 
the sad exile of Orestes, and my father's fate, whom thou didst once fondle 
in thy arms, in vain, alas! for thee and for thy friends?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Ah yes! in vain; but still I could not bear to leave him thus; 
and so I added this to my journey that I sought his grave, and, falling 
thereupon, wept o'er its desolation; then did I open the wine-skin, my 
gift to thy guests, and poured a libation, and set myrtle-sprigs round 
the tomb. And lo! upon the grave itself I saw a black ram had been offered, 
and there was blood, not long poured forth, and severed locks of auburn 
hair. Much I wondered, my daughter, who had dared approach the tomb; certainly 
'twas no Argive. Nay, thy brother may perchance have come by stealth, and 
going thither have done honour to his father's wretched grave. Look at 
the hair, compare it with thy own, to see if the colour of these cut locks 
is the same; for children in whose veins runs the same father's blood have 
a close resemblance in many features.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
Old sir, thy words are unworthy of a wise man, if thou thinkest 
my own brave brother would have come to this land by stealth for fear of 
Aegisthus. In the next place, how should our hair correspond? His is the 
hair of a gallant youth trained up in manly sports, mine a woman's curled 
and combed; nay, that is a hopeless clue. Besides, thou couldst find many, 
whose hair is of the same colour, albeit not sprung from the same blood. 
No, maybe 'twas some stranger cut off his hair in pity at his tomb, or 
one that came to spy this land privily.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Put thy foot in the print of his shoe and mark whether it correspond 
with thine, my child.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN
ELECTRA

lines.value:
Hast thou no mark, in case thy brother should come, whereby 
to recognize the weaving of thy loom, the robe wherein I snatched him from 
death that day?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
Dost thou forget I was still a babe when Orestes left the country? 
and even if I had woven him a robe, how should he, a mere child then, be 
wearing the same now, unless our clothes and bodies grow together?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Where are these guests? I fain would question them face to 
face about thy brother.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
As he speaks, ORESTES and PYLADES come out of the 
hut.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: There they are, in haste to leave the house.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Well born, it seems, but that may be a sham; for there be plenty 
such prove knaves. Still I give them greeting.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
All hail, father! To which of thy friends, Electra, does this 
old relic of mortality belong?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: This is he who nursed my sire, sir stranger.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
What! do I behold him who removed thy brother out of harm's 
way?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Behold the man who saved his life; if, that is, he liveth still.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Ha! why does he look so hard at me, as if he were examining 
the bright device on silver coin? Is he finding in me a likeness to some 
other?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Maybe he is glad to see in thee a companion of Orestes.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: A man I love full well. But why is he walking round me?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I, too, am watching his movements with amaze, sir stranger.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
My honoured mistress, my daughter Electra, return thanks to 
heaven,-
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: For past or present favours? which?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: That thou hast found a treasured prize, which God is now revealing.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Hear me invoke the gods. But what dost thou mean, old man?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Behold before thee, my child, thy nearest and dearest.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: I have long feared thou wert not in thy sound senses
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Not in my sound senses, because I see thy brother?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: What mean'st thou, aged friend, by these astounding words?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: That I see Orestes, Agamemnon's son, before me.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: What mark dost see that I can trust?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
A scar along his brow, where he fell and cut himself one day 
in his father's home when chasing a fawn with thee.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Is it possible? True; I see the mark of the fall.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Dost hesitate then to embrace thy own dear brother?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
No! not any longer, old friend; for my soul is convinced by 
the tokens thou showest. O my brother, thou art come at last, and I embrace 
thee, little as I ever thought to.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: And thee to my bosom at last I press.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I never thought that it would happen.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: All hope in me was also dead.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Aye, thy one and only champion, if I can but safely draw to 
shore the cast I mean to throw; and I feel sure I shall; else must we cease 
to believe in gods, if wrong is to triumph o'er right.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Enough! sweet though the rapture of this greeting be, I must 
wait and return it hereafter. Do thou, old friend so timely met, tell me 
how I am to avenge me on my father's murderer, and on my mother, the partner 
in his guilty marriage. Have I still in Argos any band of kindly friends? 
or am I, like my fortunes, bankrupt altogether? With whom am I to league 
myself? by night or day shall I advance? point out a road for me to take 
against these foes of mine.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
My son, thou hast no friend now in thy hour of adversity. No! 
that is a piece of rare good luck, to find another share thy fortunes alike 
for better and for worse. Thou art of every friend completely reft, all 
hope is gone from thee; be sure of what I tell thee; on thy own arm and 
fortune art thou wholly thrown to win thy father's home and thy city.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: What must I do to compass this result?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Slay Thyestes' son and thy mother.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: I came to win that victor's crown, but how can I attain it?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Thou wouldst never achieve it if thou didst enter the walls.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Are they manned with guards and armed sentinels?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Aye truly; for he is afraid of thee, and cannot sleep secure.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Well then, do thou next propose a scheme, old friend.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Hear me a moment; an idea has just occurred to me.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: May thy counsel prove good, and my perception keen!
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I saw Aegisthus, as I was slowly pacing hither-
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: I welcome thy words. Where was he?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Not far from these fields, at his stables.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: What was he doing? I see a gleam of hope after our helplessness.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I thought he was preparing a feast for the Nymphs.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
In return for the bringing up of children or in anticipation 
of a birth?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: All I know is this, he was preparing to sacrifice oxen.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: How many were with him? or was he alone with his servants?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: There was no Argive there; only a band of his own followers.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Is it possible that any of them will recognize me, old man?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: They are only servants, and they have never even seen thee.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Will they support me, if I prevail?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Yes, that is the way of slaves, luckily for thee.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: On what pretext can I approach him?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Go to some place where he will see thee as he sacrifices.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: His estate is close to the road then, I suppose.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Yes, and when he sees thee there, he will invite thee to the 
feast.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: So help me God! He shall rue his invitation.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: After that, form thy own plan according to circumstances.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Good advice! But my mother, where is she?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: At Argos; but she will yet join her husband for the feast.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Why did she not come forth with him?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: From fear of the citizens' reproach she stayed behind.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: I understand; she knows that the city suspects her.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Just so; her wickedness makes her hated.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: How shall I slay her and him together?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Mine be the preparation of my mother's slaying!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Well, as for the other, fortune will favour us.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Our old friend here must help us both.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Aye, that will I; but wnat is thy scheme for slaying thy mother?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
Go, old man, and tell Clytemnestra from me that I have given 
birth to a son.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Some time ago, or quite recently?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Ten days ago, which are the days of my purification.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Suppose it done; but how doth this help towards slaying thy 
mother?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: She will come, when she hears of my confinement.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: What! dost think she cares aught for thee, my child?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Oh yes! she will weep no doubt over my child's low rank.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Perhaps she may; but go back again to the point.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Her death is certain, if she comes.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: In that case, let her come right up to the door of the house.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
Why then it were a little thing to turn her steps into the 
road to Hades' halls.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Oh! to see this one day, then die!
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: First of all, old friend, act as my brother's guide.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: To the place where Aegisthus is now sacrificing to the gods?
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: Then go, find my mother and give her my message.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Aye, that I will, so that she shall think the very words are 
thine.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value: I will go, if some one will show me the way.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I will myself conduct thee nothing loth.
lines.speaker: OLD MAN

lines.value:
O Zeus, god of my fathers, vanquisher of my foes, have pity 
on us, for a piteous lot has ours been.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Oh! have pity on thy own descendants.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
O Hera, mistress of Mycenae's altars, grant us the victory, 
if we are asking what is right.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Yes, grant us vengeance on them for our father's death.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Thou too, my father, sent to the land of shades by wicked hands, 
and Earth, the queen of all, to whom I spread my suppliant palms, up and 
champion thy dear children. Come with all the dead to aid, all they who 
helped thee break the Phrygians' power, and all who hate ungodly crime. 
Dost hear me, father, victim of my mother's rage?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Sure am I he heareth all; but 'tis time to part. For this cause 
too I bid thee strike Aegisthus down, because, if thou fall in the struggle 
and perish, I also die; no longer number me amongst the living; for I will 
stab myself with a two-edged sword. And now will I go indoors and make 
all ready there, for, if there come good news from thee, my house shall 
ring with women's cries of joy; but, if thou art slain, a different scene 
must then ensue. These are my instructions to thee.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: ORESTES, PYLADES, the OLD MAN, and attendants, depart.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Then show thyself a man. And you, my friends, signal to me 
by cries the certain issue of this fray. Myself will keep the sword ready 
in my grasp, for I will never accept defeat, and yield my body to my enemies 
to insult.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Hark! my friends, did ye hear that noise, like to the rumbling 
of an earthquake, or am I the dupe of idle fancy? Hark! hark! once more 
that wind-borne sound swells loudly on mine ear. Electra! mistress mine! 
come forth from the house!
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value: I hear the cries of dying men; no more I know.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: I heard them too, far off, but still distinct.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Yes, the sound came stealing from afar, but yet 'twas clear.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Was it the groan of an Argive, or of my friends?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: I know not; for the cries are all confused.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: That word of thine is my death-warrant; why do I delay?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Stay, till thou learn thy fate for certain.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: No, no; we are vanquished; where are our messengers?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: They will come in time; to slay a king is no light task.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
All hail! ye victors, maidens of Mycenae, to all Orestes' friends 
his triumph I announce; Aegisthus, the murderer of Agamemnon, lies weltering 
where he fell; return thanks to heaven.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: Who art thou? What proof dost thou give of this?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Look at me, dost thou not recognize thy brother's servant?
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
O best of friends! 'twas fear that prevented me from recognizing 
thee; now I know thee well. What sayst thou? Is my father's hateful murderer 
slain?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: He is; I repeat it since it is thy wish.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
Ye gods, and justice, whose eye is on all, at last art thou 
come.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
I fain would learn the way and means my brother took to slay 
Thyestes' son.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
After we had set out from this house, we struck into the broad 
highroad, and came to the place where was the far-famed King of Mycenae. 
Now he was walking in a garden well-watered, culling a wreath of tender 
myrtle-sprays for his head, and when he saw us, he called out, "All hail! 
strangers; who are ye? whence come ye? from what country?" To him Orestes 
answered, "We are from Thessaly, on our way to Alpheus' banks to sacrifice 
to Olympian Zeus." When Aegisthus heard that, he said, "Ye must be my guests 
to-day, and share the feast, for I am even now sacrificing to the Nymphs; 
and by rising with tomorrow's light ye will be just as far upon your journey; 
now let us go within." Therewith he caught us by the hand and led us by 
the way; refuse we could not; and when we were come to the house, he gave 
command: "Bring water for my guests to wash forthwith, that they may stand 
around the altar near the laver." But Orestes answered, "'Twas but now 
we purified ourselves and washed us clean in water from the river. So if 
we strangers are to join your citizens in sacrifice, we are ready, King 
Aegisthus, and will not refuse." So ended they their private conference. 
Meantime the servants, that composed their master's bodyguard, laid aside 
their weapons, and one and all were busied at their tasks. Some brought 
the bowl to catch the blood, others took up baskets, while others kindled 
fire and set cauldrons round about the altars, and the whole house rang. 
Then did thy mother's husband take the barley for sprinkling, and began 
casting it upon the hearth with these words, "Ye Nymphs, who dwell among 
the rocks, grant that I may often sacrifice with my wife, the daughter 
of Tyndareus, within my halls, as happily as now, and ruin seize my foes!"
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: whereby he meant Orestes and thyself
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
O light of day! O bright careering sun! O earth! and night 
erewhile my only day; now may I open my eyes in freedom, for Aegisthus 
is dead, my father's murderer. Come friends, let me bring out whate'er 
my house contains to deck his head and wreath with crowns my conquering 
brother's brow.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
ORESTES and PYLADES enter, followed by attendants who are bearing the 
body of Aegisthus.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Hail! glorious victor, Orestes, son of a sire who won the day 
'neath Ilium's walls, accept this wreath to bind about the tresses of thy 
hair. Not in vain hast thou run thy course unto the goal and reached thy 
home again; no! but thou hast slain thy foe, Aegisthus, the murderer of 
our father. Thou too, O Pylades, trusty squire, whose training shows thy 
father's sterling worth, receive a garland from my hand, for thou no less 
than he hast a share in this emprise; and so I pray, good luck be thine 
for ever!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
First recognize the gods, Electra, as being the authors of 
our fortune, and then praise me their minister and fate's. Yea, I come 
from having slain Aegisthus in very deed, no mere pretence; and to make 
thee the more certain of this, I am bringing thee his corpse, which, if 
thou wilt, expose for beasts to rend, or set it upon a stake for birds, 
the children of the air, to prey upon; for now is he thy slave, once called 
thy lord and master.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: I am ashamed to utter my wishes.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: What is it? speak out, for thou art through the gates of fear.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
I am ashamed to flout the dead, for fear some spite assail 
me.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: No one would blame thee for this.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Our folk are hard to please, and love to blame.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Speak all thy mind, sister; for we entered on this feud with 
him on terms admitting not of truce.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Turning to the corpse of Aegisthus
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Spurning the corpse with her foot
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Terrible alike his crime and your revenge; for mighty is the 
power of justice.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
'Tis well. Carry his body within the house and hide it, sirrahs, 
that when my mother comes, she may not see his corpse before she is smitten 
herself.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
PYLADES and the attendants take the body into the 
hut.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Hold! let us strike out another scheme.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: How now? Are those allies from Mycenae whom I see?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: No, 'tis my mother, that bare me.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Full into the net she is rushing, oh, bravely!
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: See how proudly she rides in her chariot and fine robes!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: What must we do to our mother? Slay her?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: What! has pity seized thee at sight of her?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: O God! how can I slay her that bare and suckled me?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Slay her as she slew thy father and mine.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: O Phoebus, how foolish was thy oracle-
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Where Apollo errs, who shall be wise?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: In bidding me commit this crime-my mother's murder!
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: How canst thou be hurt by avenging thy father?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Though pure before, I now shall carry into exile the stain 
of a mother's blood.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Still, if thou avenge not thy father, thou wilt fail in thy 
duty.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: And if I slay my mother, I must pay the penalty to her.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
And so must thou to him, if thou resign the avenging of our 
father.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Surely it was a fiend in the likeness of the god that ordered 
this!
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Seated on the holy tripod? I think not so.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: I cannot believe this oracle was meant.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: Turn not coward! Cast not thy manliness away!
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Am I to devise the same crafty scheme for her?
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value: The self-same death thou didst mete out to her lord Aegisthus.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
I will go in; 'tis an awful task I undertake; an awful deed 
I have to do; still if it is Heaven's will, be it so; I loathe and yet 
I love the enterprise.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
As ORESTES withdraws into the hut, CLYTEMNESTRA enters in a chariot. 
Her attendants are hand-maidens attired in gorgeous 
apparel.
lines.speaker: ORESTES

lines.value:
Alight from the car, ye Trojan maids, and take my hand that 
I may step down from the chariot. With Trojan spoils the temples of the 
gods are decked, but I have obtained these maidens as a special gift from 
Troy, in return for my lost daughter, a trifling boon no doubt, but still 
an ornament to my house.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
And may not I, mother, take that highly-favoured hand of thine? 
I am a slave like them, an exile from my father's halls in this miserable 
abode.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: See, my servants are here; trouble not on my account.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Why, thou didst make me thy prisoner by robbing me of my home; 
like these I became a captive when my home was taken, an orphan all forlorn.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
True; but thy father plotted so wickedly against those of his 
own kin whom least of all he should have treated so. Speak I must; albeit, 
when woman gets an evil reputation, there is a feeling of bitterness against 
all she says; unfairly indeed in my case, for it were only fair to hate 
after learning the circumstances, and seeing if the object deserves it; 
otherwise, why hate at all? Now Tyndareus bestowed me on thy father not 
that I or any children I might bear should be slain. Yet he went and took 
my daughter from our house to the fleet at Aulis, persuading me that Achilles 
was to wed her; and there he held her o'er the pyre, and cut Iphigenia's 
snowy throat. Had he slain her to save his city from capture, or to benefit 
his house, or to preserve his other children, a sacrifice of one for many, 
could have pardoned him. But, as it was, his reasons for murdering my child 
were these: the wantonness of Helen and her husband's folly in not punishing 
the traitress. Still, wronged as I was, my rage had not burst forth for 
this, nor would I have slain my lord, had he not returned to me with that 
frenzied maiden and made her his mistress, keeping at once two brides beneath 
the same roof. Women maybe are given to folly, I do not deny it; this granted, 
when a husband goes astray and sets aside his own true wife, she fain will 
follow his example and find another love; and then in our case hot abuse 
is heard, while the men, who are to blame for this, escape without a word. 
Again, suppose Menelaus had been secretly snatched from his home, should 
I have had to kill Orestes to save Menelaus, my sister's husband? How would 
thy father have endured this? Was he then to escape death for slaying what 
was mine, while I was to suffer at his hands? I slew him, turning, as my 
only course, to his enemies. For which of all thy father's friends would 
have joined me in his murder? Speak all that is in thy heart, and prove 
against me with all free speech, that thy father's death was not deserved.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Justly urged! but thy justice is not free from shame; for in 
all things should every woman of sense yield to her husband. Whoso thinketh 
otherwise comes not within the scope of what I say. Remember, mother, those 
last words of thine, allowing me free utterance before thee.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Daughter, far from refusing it, I grant it again.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value: Thou wilt not, when thou hearest, wreak thy vengeance on me?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: No, indeed; I shall welcome thy opinion.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Then will I speak, and this shall be the prelude of my speech: 
Ah, mother mine! would thou hadst had a better heart; for though thy beauty 
and Helen's win you praises well deserved, yet are ye akin in nature, pair 
of wantons, unworthy of Castor. She was carried off, 'tis true, but her 
fall was voluntary: and thou hast slain the bravest soul in Hellas, excusing 
thyself on the ground that thou didst kill a husband to avenge a daughter; 
the world does not know thee so well as I do, thou who before ever thy 
daughter's death was decided, yea, soon as thy lord had started from his 
home, wert combing thy golden tresses at thy mirror. That wife who, when 
her lord is gone from home, sets to beautifying herself, strike off from 
virtue's list; for she has no need to carry her beauty abroad, save she 
is seeking some mischief. Of all the wives in Hellas thou wert the only 
one I know who wert overjoyed when Troy's star was in the ascendant, while, 
if it set, thy brow was clouded, since thou hadst no wish that Agamemnon 
should return from Troy. And yet thou couldst have played a virtuous part 
to thy own glory. The husband thou hadst was no whit inferior to Aegisthus, 
for he it was whom Hellas chose to be her captain. And when thy sister 
Helen wrought that deed of shame, thou couldst have won thyself great glory, 
for vice is a warning and calls attention to virtue. If, as thou allegest, 
my father slew thy daughter, what is the wrong I and my brother have done 
thee? How was it thou didst not bestow on us our father's halls after thy 
husband's death, instead of bartering them to buy a paramour? Again, thy 
husband is not exiled for thy son's sake, nor is he slain to avenge my 
death, although by him this life is quenched twice as much as e'er my sister's 
was; so if murder is to succeed murder in requital, I and thy son Orestes 
must slay thee to avenge our father; if that was just, why so is this. 
Whoso fixes his gaze on wealth or noble birth and weds a wicked woman, 
is a fool; better is a humble partner in his home, if she be virtuous, 
than a proud one.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Chance rules the marriages of women; some I see turn out well, 
others ill amongst mankind.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
Daughter, 'twas ever thy nature to love thy father. This too 
one finds; some sons cling to their father, others have a deeper affection 
for their mother. I will forgive thee, for myself am not so exceeding glad 
at the deed that I have done, my child. But thou,-why thus unwashed and 
clad in foul attire, now that the days of thy lying-in are accomplished? 
Ah me, for my sorry schemes! I have goaded my husband into anger more than 
e'er I should have done.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Thy sorrow comes too late; the hour of remedy has gone from 
thee; my father is dead. Yet why not recall that exile, thy own wandering 
son?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
I am afraid; 'tis my interest, not his that I regard. For they 
say he is wroth for his father's murder.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Why, then, dost thou encourage thy husband's bitterness against 
us?
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: 'Tis his way; thou too hast a stubborn nature.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value: Because I am grieved; yet will I check my spirit.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: I promise then he shall no longer oppress thee.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value: From living in my home he grows too proud.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Now there! 'tis thou that art fanning the quarrel into new 
life.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value: I say no more; my dread of him is even what it is.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Peace! Enough of this. Why didst thou summon me, my child?
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Thou hast heard, I suppose, of my confinement; for this I pray 
thee, since I know not how, offer the customary sacrifice on the tenth 
day after birth, for I am a novice herein, never having had a child before.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: This is work for another, even for her who delivered thee.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value: I was all alone in my travail and at the babe's birth.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: Dost live so far from neighbours?
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value: No one cares to make the poor his friends.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
Well, I will go to offer to the gods a sacrifice for the child's 
completion of the days; and when I have done thee this service, I will 
seek the field where my husband is sacrificing to the Nymphs. Take this 
chariot hence, my servants, and tie the horses to the stalls; and when 
ye think that I have finished my offering to the gods, attend me, for I 
must likewise pleasure my lord.
lines.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA

lines.value:
Enter our humble cottage; but, prithee, take care that my smoke 
grimed walls soil not thy robes; now wilt thou offer to the gods a fitting 
sacrifice. There stands the basket ready, and the knife is sharpened, the 
same that slew the bull, by whose side thou soon wilt lie a corpse; and 
thou shalt be his bride in Hades' halls whose wife thou wast on earth. 
This is the boon I will grant thee, while thou shalt pay me for my father's 
blood.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value: ELECTRA follows her into the hut.
lines.speaker: ELECTRA

lines.value:
ORESTES and ELECTRA come out of the hut, followed by attendants who 
are carrying the two corpses. The following lines between ELECTRA, ORESTES 
and the CHORUS are chanted.
lines.speaker: CHORUS
